Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]:  HTML tags supported in CommonMark not rendered in nuget.org documentation page" (#9186) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

NuGet.exe

### Product Version

6.0

### Worked before?

Not sure

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

html/css not supported in readme file when uploaded to [Nuget.org](https://www.nuget.org/packages/austen.ConsoleHelperLibrary/)

The [documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/nuget-org/package-readme-on-nuget-org#supported-markdown-features) says it supports CommonMark compliant Markdown.

when using [spec.commonmark.org](https://spec.commonmark.org/dingus/?text=%3Ch1%20align%3D%22center%22%3E%20ConsoleLibraryHelper%20%3C%2Fh1%3E%0A%0A%3Cp%20align%3D%22center%22%3E%20%3Ca%20href%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nuget.org%2Fpackages%2Fausten.ConsoleHelperLibrary%2F%22%20alt%3D%22%22%3E%20%3Cimg%20src%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fimg.shields.io%2Fnuget%2Fv%2Fausten.ConsoleHelperLibrary%22%20%2F%3E%3C%2Fa%3E%20%3Ca%20href%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nuget.org%2Fpackages%2Fausten.ConsoleHelperLibrary%2F%22%20alt%3D%22%22%3E%20%3Cimg%20src%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fimg.shields.io%2Fnuget%2Fdt%2Fausten.ConsoleHelperLibrary%22%20%2F%3E%3C%2Fa%3E%20%3Ca%20href%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fbadgen.net%2Fbadge%2Ficon%2Fgithub%3Ficon%3Dgithub%26label%22%20alt%3D%22%22%3E%20%3Cimg%20src%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fbadgen.net%2Fbadge%2Ficon%2Fgithub%3Ficon%3Dgithub%26label%22%20%2F%3E%3C%2Fa%3E%20%3Ca%20href%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fimg.shields.io%2Fgithub%2Flicense%2Faus10code%2FConsoleHelperLibrary%22%20alt%3D%22%22%3E%20%3Cimg%20src%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fimg.shields.io%2Fgithub%2Flicense%2Faus10code%2FConsoleHelperLibrary%22%20%2F%3E%3C%2Fa%3E%20%3C%2Fp%3E) with the following code it works on the generator but not on [Nuget.org](https://www.nuget.org/packages/austen.ConsoleHelperLibrary/) as shown by my package

This readme correctly displays on [Github](https://github.com/aus10code/ConsoleHelperLibrary). I'm not sure if Nuget.org uses the same parser

**image of issue below**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/62197117/183241194-8550db9c-aa1c-49a9-8123-b4c4727678e1.png)

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "syntax highlighting" (#9179) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Summary of the changes (in less than 80 characters):

* Add feature flag
* Use third party library highlight.js support highlighting on client side
* Able highlight readme on Manage, display package, upload package pages. 
* Support on embedded/legacy readme on upload, display, manage page. 
Before: 
![beforeReadme](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64443925/181118679-18dcfa9d-816e-4f7b-8612-9c83c35207a3.png)
After: 
upload page: 
![uploadpage](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64443925/182669856-849edee4-755c-455f-900c-ed1ff0a11b44.png)

display page
![display](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64443925/182669892-75fd8345-effa-4a7d-8236-3738572c0c64.png)

manage page: 
![manage](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64443925/182669999-ec574e76-5181-45db-bd9c-8300c8944fc0.png)


If you have more question about the approach, please take a look at spec. 

Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/8632

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Newline breaks in markdown" (#9185) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Describe the bug

Possible regression. This bug seems to be back:
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/8642

Linkebreaks are inserted after each badge image. No empty line is present in the source markdown.

### Repro Steps

Embed README.md in NuGet package:
https://github.com/flobernd/zysharp-metaprogramming/commit/a4fd3f8109e9baf34270422910c95b82495f66a4#diff-b335630551682c19a781afebcf4d07bf978fb1f8ac04c6bf87428ed5106870f5

### Expected Behavior

No linebreaks are visible after each badge image.

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "[Bug]: Path or extension too long when publishing in Visual Studio" (#11968) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

NuGet.exe

### Product Version

VS2022 Preview

### Worked before?

I'm not sure it seems it never worked using the VS UI for my solution.

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

I'm trying to publish from Visual Studio using the Visual Studio user interface. While everything seems to work using msbuild.exe and dotnet.exe. It doesn't work using the UI. The error is quite self describing. It simply tells me that the file, path or extension name is too long, but this is something I cannot control. It seems that the source of the error is this:

Of currently using the Preview Version of VS2022, but it also doesn't work for VS2022 official version..

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: PackageSourceProvider.UpdatePackageSource does not enable a previously disabled source." (#12008) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

NuGet SDK

### Product Version

5.10.0

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

In class `NuGet.Configuration.PackageSourceProvider`, the method:
```
public void UpdatePackageSource(PackageSource source, bool updateCredentials, bool updateEnabled)
```
does not apply the configuration changes required when `source.IsEnabled` is being updated from `false` to `true` (when `updateEnabled` is `true`, indicating that the update should be applied). I suspect that the problem is [here](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/3ec6f02943fa8e70ea224eb31dd94288dbf179d0/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Configuration/PackageSource/PackageSourceProvider.cs#L526):
```
disabledSourceItem = disabledSourcesSection?.GetFirstItemWithAttribute<AddItem>(ConfigurationConstants.KeyAttribute, sourceToUpdate.ElementName);
```
where `sourceToUpdate.Key` should be used as the last argument. Note that `sourceToUpdate.ElementName` is always the constant `ConfigurationConstants.Add`, which does not seem to be what's wanted here.


### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[DCR]: Make error NU5104 more informative" (#11911) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: ### NuGet Product(s) Affected NuGet.exe, MSBuild.exe, dotnet.exe ### Current Behavior When attempting to create a package from a project that depends on a prerelease version of another package, error NU5104 is thrown with the following message: > A stable release of a package should not have a prerelease dependency. Either modify the version spec of dependency "Upstream.Dependency [1.0.0-pre, )" or update the version field in the nuspec. ### Desired Behavior The error message should be updated to explain how to override it: > A stable release of a package should not have a prerelease dependency. Either modify the version spec of dependency "Upstream.Dependency [1.0.0-pre, )", update the version field in the nuspec, or specify the -AllowPrereleaseDependencies option. ### Additional Context _No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "How can I  programmatically obtain the NU errors" (#11939) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### Discussed in https://github.com/NuGet/Home/discussions/11938
Originally posted by **Smartisa** July 3, 2022 I can check the "project assets. json" file to get the log, but how can I programmatically obtain the NU errors? ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47079990/177030593-99a9fde4-ff16-49ca-a80a-0a988613df04.png)

### NuGet Product Used

NuGet.exe

### Product Version

6.0

### Worked before?

Not sure

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

html/css not supported in readme file when uploaded to [Nuget.org](https://www.nuget.org/packages/austen.ConsoleHelperLibrary/)

The [documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/nuget-org/package-readme-on-nuget-org#supported-markdown-features) says it supports CommonMark compliant Markdown.

when using [spec.commonmark.org](https://spec.commonmark.org/dingus/?text=%3Ch1%20align%3D%22center%22%3E%20ConsoleLibraryHelper%20%3C%2Fh1%3E%0A%0A%3Cp%20align%3D%22center%22%3E%20%3Ca%20href%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nuget.org%2Fpackages%2Fausten.ConsoleHelperLibrary%2F%22%20alt%3D%22%22%3E%20%3Cimg%20src%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fimg.shields.io%2Fnuget%2Fv%2Fausten.ConsoleHelperLibrary%22%20%2F%3E%3C%2Fa%3E%20%3Ca%20href%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nuget.org%2Fpackages%2Fausten.ConsoleHelperLibrary%2F%22%20alt%3D%22%22%3E%20%3Cimg%20src%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fimg.shields.io%2Fnuget%2Fdt%2Fausten.ConsoleHelperLibrary%22%20%2F%3E%3C%2Fa%3E%20%3Ca%20href%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fbadgen.net%2Fbadge%2Ficon%2Fgithub%3Ficon%3Dgithub%26label%22%20alt%3D%22%22%3E%20%3Cimg%20src%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fbadgen.net%2Fbadge%2Ficon%2Fgithub%3Ficon%3Dgithub%26label%22%20%2F%3E%3C%2Fa%3E%20%3Ca%20href%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fimg.shields.io%2Fgithub%2Flicense%2Faus10code%2FConsoleHelperLibrary%22%20alt%3D%22%22%3E%20%3Cimg%20src%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fimg.shields.io%2Fgithub%2Flicense%2Faus10code%2FConsoleHelperLibrary%22%20%2F%3E%3C%2Fa%3E%20%3C%2Fp%3E) with the following code it works on the generator but not on [Nuget.org](https://www.nuget.org/packages/austen.ConsoleHelperLibrary/) as shown by my package

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Nuget package manager does not highlight selected package when it has no focus" (#12006) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/t/Nuget-package-manager-does-not-highlight/10110029)._

---
In the "Manage NuGet packages" window there is a list of packages (three sub-tabs with those, but it behaves the same in all of them). When you select an item there it is higlighted and details are displayed on the right, but as soon as the window loses focus, that highlight in the list is removed. This is inconsistent with every other list in VS (see solution explorer and find results, they both don't have focus but still show the selected element).

Repro steps:
1. Open NuGet package manager window
2. Select on any package in the list
3. Notice it is highlighted.
4. Press the tab key.

Notice the highlight disappears.

Alternatively, instead of just pressing tab in step 4, click an item in solution explorer to get the focus out of the package manager tab (folder preferably).

Also, getting the focus back into the package manager does not restore the highlight unless you tab through to the list explicitly.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Add `interactive` option for `dotnet pack` " (#12005) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

dotnet.exe

### The Elevator Pitch

Today, it too simple to create a package using the following commands:
```
> dotnet new classlib
> dotnet pack
```
However, this also means that a lot of defaults as assumed like the package name, package version, and misses out on some of the important metadata like:
 - README
 - license

There is no easy way to be able to create these metadata into the package. The only ways available requires either Visual Studio (Package Properties UI) or a text editor (VS Code) to directly edit the csproj. We need an easy interactive mode for command line developers to include the required metadata in an easy way without having to refer documentation on their syntax.

### Proposal
Provide an interactive way for developers top enter the required metadata for a package. Something like:
```
> dotnet pack -i
name: <default: the current directory name>
version: <default: 1.0.0>
description: <default: Package description>
author: <default: empty-string>
license: <default:ISC>
README: <default: location to the README in the root directory>
```

### Additional Context and Details

This can improve the quality of packages, by default.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "nuget pack doesn't support nuspec group elements" (#2300) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
The nuspec used:

```
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<package >
  <metadata>
    <id>$id$</id>
    <version>$version$</version>
    <title>$title$</title>
    <authors>$author$</authors>
    <owners>$author$</owners>
    <licenseUrl>http://LICENSE_URL_HERE_OR_DELETE_THIS_LINE</licenseUrl>
    <projectUrl>http://PROJECT_URL_HERE_OR_DELETE_THIS_LINE</projectUrl>
    <iconUrl>http://ICON_URL_HERE_OR_DELETE_THIS_LINE</iconUrl>
    <requireLicenseAcceptance>true</requireLicenseAcceptance>
    <description>$description$</description>
    <copyright>Copyright 2016</copyright>
    <tags>FirstTag SecondTag</tags>
    <language>en-us</language>
   <!-- <references>   
       <reference file="DepDepLib.dll"></reference>
    </references>-->
<frameworkAssemblies>
  <frameworkAssembly assemblyName="System.ComponentModel.DataAnnotations" targetFramework="net40" />
  <frameworkAssembly assemblyName="System.ServiceModel" targetFramework="net40" />
</frameworkAssemblies>
<dependencies> 
<group targetFramework="sl30">
      <dependency id="Microsoft.Net.Http1" version="2.2.29" />
      <dependency id="bootstrap1" version="3.3.6" />
      <dependency id="DepPackage1" version="1.0.0" />
</group>
<group targetFramework=".netframework45">
      <dependency id="Microsoft.Net.Http" version="1.2.29" />
      <dependency id="bootstrap" version="1.3.6" />
      <dependency id="DepPackage" version="2.0.0" />
</group>
</dependencies>
  </metadata>
  <files>
    <file src="FilesFolder\*.*" target="FilesFolder\$id$" /> 
    <file src="EmptyFolder\*.*" target="EmptyFolder" /> 
  </files>

</package>
```

In the resulting package, appeared a flat list of dependencies.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Microsoft Security Advisory CVE 2022-30184 | .NET Information Disclosure Vulnerability" (#62) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody: # Microsoft Security Advisory CVE 2022-30184 | .NET Information Disclosure Vulnerability ## Executive summary Microsoft is releasing this security advisory to provide information about a vulnerability in .NET 6.0 and .NET Core 3.1, NuGet (NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat version range from 3.5.0 to 6.2.0). This advisory also provides guidance on what developers can do to update their applications to remove this vulnerability. A vulnerability exists in .NET 6.0, .NET Core 3.1, and NuGet clients (NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat version range from 3.5.0 to 6.2.0) where a nuget.org credential could be leaked. ## Discussion Discussion for this issue can be found at https://github.com/nuget/home/issues. (TBD) ## Mitigation factors Microsoft has not identified any mitigating factors for this vulnerability. ## Affected software ### NuGet & NuGet Packages - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 6.2.0 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 6.0.1 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 5.11.1 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 5.9.1 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 5.7.1 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 5.2.0 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 4.9.4 version or earlier. ### .NET SDK(s) - Any .NET 6.0 application running on .NET 6.0.5 or earlier. - Any .NET 3.1 application running on .NET Core 3.1.25 or earlier. ### How do I know if I am affected? If you have a NuGet.exe, NuGet package, or .NET SDK with a version listed in [affected software](#affected-software), you're exposed to the vulnerability. ### How do I fix the issue? To fix the issue, please install the latest version of .NET 6.0 or .NET Core 3.1 and NuGet (NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat version 4.9.5, 5.7.2, 5.9.2, 5.11.2, 6.0.2, 6.2.1). If you have installed one or more .NET SDKs through Visual Studio, Visual Studio will prompt you to update Visual Studio, which will also update your .NET SDKs. You can get the version of NuGet.exe by running the `nuget` command. You should see an output like the following: ``` NuGet Version: 6.0.0.280 usage: NuGet [args] [options] Type 'NuGet help ' for help on a specific command. To install additional .NET Core runtimes or SDKs: https://www.nuget.org/downloads ``` If you're using NuGet.exe 6.2.0 or lower, you should download and install 6.2.1 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.2.1/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 6.0.1 or lower, you should download and install 6.0.2 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.0.2/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 5.11.1 or lower, you should download and install 5.11.2 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v5.11.2/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 5.9.1 or lower, you should download and install 5.9.2 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v5.9.2/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 5.7.1 or lower, you should download and install 5.7.2 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v5.7.2/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 5.2.0 or lower, you should download and install 5.2.1 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v5.2.1/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 4.9.4 or lower, you should download and install 4.9.5 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v4.9.5/nuget.exe. You can list the versions you have installed by running the `dotnet --info` command. You should see an output like the following: ``` .NET Core SDK (reflecting any global.json): Version: 6.0.300 Commit: 8473146e7d Runtime Environment: OS Name: Windows OS Version: 10.0.18363 OS Platform: Windows RID: win10-x64 Base Path: C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\6.0.300\ Host (useful for support): Version: 6.0.5 Commit: 8473146e7d .NET Core SDKs installed: 6.0.300 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk] .NET Core runtimes installed: Microsoft.AspNetCore.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App] Microsoft.NETCore.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.NETCore.App] Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App] To install additional .NET Core runtimes or SDKs: https://aka.ms/dotnet-download ``` If you're using .NET Core 6.0, you should download and install Runtime 6.0.6 or SDK 6.0.106 (for Visual Studio 2022 v17.0) or SDK 6.0.301 (for Visual Studio 2022 v17.2) from https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/6.0. If you're using .NET Core 3.1, you should download and install Runtime 3.1.26 or SDK 3.1.420 (for Visual Studio 2019 v16.9 or Visual Studio 2011 16.11 or Visual Studio 2022 17.0 or Visual Studio 2022 17.1) from https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/3.1 .NET 6.0 and .NET Core 3.1 updates are also available from Microsoft Update. To access this either type "Check for updates" in your Windows search, or open Settings, choose Update & Security and then click Check for Updates. Once you have installed the updated runtime or SDK, restart your apps for the update to take effect. Additionally, if you've deployed self-contained applications targeting any of the impacted versions, these applications are also vulnerable and must be recompiled and redeployed. ## Other Information ### Reporting Security Issues If you have found a potential security issue in .NET 5 or .NET 6.0, please email details to [secure@microsoft.com](secure@microsoft.com). Reports may qualify for the Microsoft .NET Core & .NET 5 Bounty. Details of the Microsoft .NET Bounty Program including terms and conditions are at [https://aka.ms/corebounty](https://aka.ms/corebounty). ### Support You can ask questions about this issue on GitHub in the .NET GitHub organization. The main repo is located at [https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client). The [Announcements repo](https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues) will contain this bulletin as an issue and will include a link to a discussion issue. You can ask questions in the linked discussion issue. ### Disclaimer The information provided in this advisory is provided "as is" without warranty of any kind. Microsoft disclaims all warranties, either express or implied, including the warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose. In no event shall Microsoft Corporation or its suppliers be liable for any damages whatsoever including direct, indirect, incidental, consequential, loss of business profits or special damages, even if Microsoft Corporation or its suppliers have been advised of the possibility of such damages. Some states do not allow the exclusion or limitation of liability for consequential or incidental damages so the foregoing limitation may not apply. ### External Links [CVE 2022-30184](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2022-30184) ### Revisions V1.0 (June 14, 2022): Advisory published. _Version 1.0_ _Last Updated 2022-06-14_
